name: PANTHRO: The Strongest Dever in the World! (Fighter 14/ Bard 16/ RDD 10)
author: Valerfor

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
(FIGHTER 14/ BARD 16/ RDD 10)
RACE: Half-Orc
ALIGNMENT: CG (Any non-lawful)
PLAYABILITY: PvM & PvP 1-40 lvl

STARTING/ ENDING STATS:
STR -  20 (44)
DEX -  10
CON - 14 (16)
INT –  12 (14)
WIS -  08
CHA - 06 (08)

Hit Points: 440

Skill Points: 181

Discipline: 43 (60)
Lore: 8 (26)
Perform: 31 (30)
Tumble: 40 (40)
Spellcraft: 28 (30)
UMD: 31 (30)

BAB:   26 (Four Attacks)
AB:     +47/ +42/ +37/ +32 (Heavy Flail)
DMG: 1D10 +31/ 17-20 X2 (Heavy Flail)

Saving Throws (Fort/Ref/Will): 25/ 19/ 22 (Base)
Saving Throws (Fort/Ref/Will): 31/ 25/ 28 (Saves Versus Spells)

Naked/ Armoured AC: 24 (Naked)/ 32 (Full Plate)/ 36 (Full Plate & Shield, +2 Dex)

Spellcasting: UMD
Bard/ Curse Song – Duration: 15 Rounds each
Immunity to Fire, Paralysis & Sleep. Darkvision. Dragon Breath 1/ Day for 6D10 Fire Damage
Bard Song 16TH lvl: +2 AB/ +3 DMG/ +2 Fort/ +3 Will/ +2 Ref/ +20 HP's/ +5 AC/ +4 to all Skills
Devastating Critical DC: 47 (53) – Highest Dev. Critical DC after use of Curse song. (55) DC total

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Nothing much to say here, it does what it says on the tin. He does have an Exp penalty due to race & he doesn't have spells (just a plain' old song) but all of those things just collapse under the sheer amount of horsepower he delivers. If he was an engine, he would be a Top Fuel one. Get your two-hander out, load your wands for back-up in case of emergency & just destroy everything you see.

Have fun,

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
You confused bard with barbarian concerning the alignment restrictions...
EDIT: Not that it would affect the build itself in any way, just noticed that his alignment is incorrect.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Er, bard is any non-lawful, same as barbarian...

Seems like a strapping fellow, Valerfor! Singing a jaunty tune while knocking baddies out of the park - I like him.

Cheers

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content: Had to check, because I was so sure that bards had to be part neutral. Confused it with the old rules it appears, never even tried in NWN...

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This is plain Madness!
A max strength halforc RDD bosted by the songs of a lvl 16 bard!
RUN!!!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: This is plain Madness!
A max strength halforc RDD bosted by the songs of a lvl 16 bard!
RUN!!!
It's actually made me feel a little ill, Mick. I've been playing Valerfor's very own Savage Strike (Fighter 12/ Rogue 2/ CoT 26) because I just wanted to wallop things hard and often atm, and then he pops up with this fellow, having not posted a new build in ages.

Still, I know where I'm looking next time I feel like some pure bashiness combined with a lilting melody!

posts.content:
Thanks, wildleaf, the image is from deviant art & it was my main inspiration for this build. You can find the artist's page below.

posts.author: ximobiwa
posts.content: Hi, great build. How does it compare with your older one, 'MOGHEDIEN – Melody of the Dark'. Would you say it's better to take Blackguard or Fighter class when thinking about more overall survivability (fast kill vs higher save throws) of these builds? Or even to Mick's Paragon of Pain: Bard 8/ RDD 10/ Blackguard 22?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Heya Xim,

I take it that you refer to Moghedien's dev-crit version that I posted at the end right? Well, Moghedien will end up slightly stronger in the end, she is a more complete, more capable build overall even though she has four less strength than Panthro has and no ews. As far as starting power and ease of play though, he is edging her out. Panthro is powerful but also simple & fun if I had to describe him in a few words.

Mick's paragon of pain is a very powerful build as well. Different flavour but equally destructive so to speak.

posts.author: ximobiwa
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Heya Xim,

I take it that you refer to Moghedien's dev-crit version that I posted at the end right? Well, Moghedien will end up slightly stronger in the end, she is a more complete, more capable build overall even though she has four less strength than Panthro has and no ews. As far as starting power and ease of play though, he is edging her out. Panthro is powerful but also simple & fun if I had to describe him in a few words.

Mick's paragon of pain is a very powerful build as well. Different flavour but equally destructive so to speak.
Yes, exactly this one. Thanks for your answer, I appreciate it. Personally I loved my build in NWN2 which was F/B/RDD/BG but unfortunately NWN1 is limited to 3 classes and I was trying to find something similar. I am not sure if I should be posting in this thread as posting in MOGHEDIEN could be considered necroing, but as I am sure I will be modyfying it a bit to suit myself (and most likely making the build weaker but more fun to me) how essential is ESF: Perform feat to this build? Do ten additional points to perform matter that much?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
If you are used to your Fighter/ Bard/ Blackguard/ RDD in NWN II then any of the following will be appropriate for you,

Bard/ Blackguard/ RDD (insane offence)
Bard/ Pale Master/ RDD (insane defence)
Bard/ Weapon Master/ RDD (tough one to make but very unique/ powerful)
Fighter/ Bard/ RDD (common as pie but tested & working, easy to level)
Barbarian/ Bard/ RDD (a powerhouse when TR is useful/ altered)
Bard/ COT/ RDD (very powerful as well, insane saves) 
etc.

What I miss from NWN II are the additional feats such as: gws, power critical, able-learner and so on...
And that the combat feats like expertise staying enabled until you tell them not to be!
Anyway, this ain't a NWN II thread, so let's move on...

As for Moghedien, it matters where you play & from the additional equipment if you need the ESF: Perform
If you have access to "epic gloves of performing" for example, then a simple swap to get your 25th level Bard Song is all you need,
then you can swap back again to your regular gloves and since the song lasts for ten real-life minutes each time, you are cool.
ESF: Perform is there for those that don't normally have access to such items & need a combination of them & the feat in order to get the full benefits.

And no, we don't have the concept of "necroing" here as long as a question/ comment is relevant for the build so feel free to discuss her in her own thread.

posts.author: ximobiwa
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: If you are used to your Fighter/ Bard/ Blackguard/ RDD in NWN II then any of the following will be appropriate for you,

Bard/ Blackguard/ RDD (insane offence)
Bard/ Pale Master/ RDD (insane defence)
Bard/ Weapon Master/ RDD (tough one to make but very unique/ powerful)
Fighter/ Bard/ RDD (common as pie but tested & working, easy to level)
Barbarian/ Bard/ RDD (a powerhouse when TR is useful/ altered)
Bard/ COT/ RDD (very powerful as well, insane saves) 
etc.

What I miss from NWN II are the additional feats such as: gws, power critical, able-learner and so on...
And that the combat feats like expertise staying enabled until you tell them not to be!
Anyway, this ain't a NWN II thread, so let's move on...

As for Moghedien, it matters where you play & from the additional equipment if you need the ESF: Perform
If you have access to "epic gloves of performing" for example, then a simple swap to get your 25th level Bard Song is all you need,
then you can swap back again to your regular gloves and since the song lasts for ten real-life minutes each time, you are cool.
ESF: Perform is there for those that don't normally have access to such items & need a combination of them & the feat in order to get the full benefits.

And no, we don't have the concept of "necroing" here as long as a question/ comment is relevant for the build so feel free to discuss her in her own thread.
I liked RDD for STR boost, mostly because I am a loot hoarder. Build is not supposed to be competitive (OCs, random modules with friends or solo, no additional mods, mostly CEP), just for fun. That is why I usually drop Great STR feats to get different ones and boost CHA or INT on base character. But it was so long when I last played NWN I am looking for good base. You intrigued me with Pale Master, this is something to look into. I usually I do not like class spells, I prefer UMD and scrolls for this. I like BG for boost to saves from CHA, and Pale Master for its own feats. I do not think Weapon Master is that fun to me - says someone to picks fighter (mostly for active different feats I could use). I think I will be looking into Bard/RDD/PM or Bard/RDD/BG, though I am undecided yet which one. I see a one handed, armored, shield type character. I guess more defensive one, but with power to withstand the enemy and hit them back.

In NWN2 I liked Epic Resilience feat :)

Other than that, thanks for your suggestions and information!

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey Val!

This is indeed a VERY STRONG build! Kudos for it!

The only two things that make me feel "sorry" about him are:

16 Bard levels and no spells.

Heavy Flail as the weapon of choice. Would be great if you could get WF and DevCrit on a Nunchaku, right?

None of these are significant, but it just makes me wonder... how could one squeeze some CHA into this build to be able to cast at least level 4 spells? Would it be viable to drop CON to 10, DEX to 8 and pump CHA up to 12, which woulf reach 14 with RDD bonus? How much weaker would he be? Or would he just have to react quicker when drinking Heals?

Cheers!


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Hey Max!

Thanks for bringing your insight into the build but I am afraid you will have to wait for EE to make fully available the CEP weapons before your first wish can come true ;)

As for the second, I am liking the idea and of course, the loss of some 80 hit points isn't the real problem here but the lack of an additional feat for either still or extend spell. Which...you can easily solve by going with Human as a base, then you can start with Str(18) Dex(08) Con(12) Int(12) Wis(08) Cha(14) and finish off with Str(42) Dex(08) Con(14) Int(14) Wis(08) Cha(16) and having the still spell and 43 ranks in taunt if you need to help your team or listen perhaps if you solo a lot.

posts.author: campgod
posts.content: Long time no see, How has everyone been? Damn good to see you guys are still here! New look, but same great builders! I can't even get past the first 4 builds without wanting to run off and try em out.

posts.author: Scythius
posts.content: Noob here, is the Heavy Flail choice simply a flavor choice? Wouldn't the Greatsword have better damage?

posts.author: gkorjax
posts.content: Just flavor and damage type considerations, in my opinion. Bashing is generally the least protected against in many worlds/etc.

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
Dragon is stronger. Maybe Dev doesn't work in Dragonshape? It's been a long time, but I seem to remember it works.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
Scythius wrote:Noob here, is the Heavy Flail choice simply a flavor choice? Wouldn't the Greatsword have better damage?
5,5 avg dmg with Flail, 7 with Greatsword. Nah.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content: Surely you have to take into account how often (and how hard, if looking at damage) the weapon crits.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thorsson wrote: Surely you have to take into account how often (and how hard, if looking at damage) the weapon crits.
Well yes, but in this instance both weapons crit at 19-20 x2. One is slashing and the other bludgeoning. The sword is 2d6 damage, the flail is 1d10, so we're looking at tiny margins - particularly given that you're expending nothing feat-wise and have colossal Str to add to your dev crit DC.

Of course, environment plays a part - who are the enemies and what is the availability of the respective weapons? For example, if I was playing Panthro in Aielund (not that I've noticed, of course - and Aielund doesn't have Dev Crit anyway) then a greatsword would be the better option because there are some brilliant ones there, but very few - if any - superb heavy flails.

Cheers

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content: Ah,sorry. I should have been clearer - is either weapon the best option? Most of your damage comes from other sources, so my point was that maybe a Scimitar was better, despite it's lower base damage, because of the increased threat range. It also has the advantage of allowing the use of a shield if you need the extra AC.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
This brute wields a two-hander for the extra damage from the 1,5 x strength bonus. But he is also a "Dever", and for a medium sized creature 19-20 is the best threat range available for a two hander. Of course you can improve on that with Improved Critical, Keen and also Ki critical if you're a Weapon master. 
Small characters, like gnomes, halflings and such can use the Scimitar with it's 18-20 threat range as a two hander, but then again, they are not quite so strong.
Now, threat range is not everything. You also have to actually land and confirm a critical hit. And here AB is crucial. On top of that you have to beat the fort save of your target with your Dev crit DC.
While waiting for all that to happen, it is good to know that you can deal some heavy damage.

posts.author: Scythius
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: Hey Max!

Thanks for bringing your insight into the build but I am afraid you will have to wait for EE to make fully available the CEP weapons before your first wish can come true ;)

As for the second, I am liking the idea and of course, the loss of some 80 hit points isn't the real problem here but the lack of an additional feat for either still or extend spell. Which...you can easily solve by going with Human as a base, then you can start with Str(18) Dex(08) Con(12) Int(12) Wis(08) Cha(14) and finish off with Str(42) Dex(08) Con(14) Int(14) Wis(08) Cha(16) and having the still spell and 43 ranks in taunt if you need to help your team or listen perhaps if you solo a lot.
Starting him as a human could indeed be interesting, as you'd have enough charisma for bard spells, and won't have to deal with the XP penalty. How much of a loss would it be for AB and damage I wonder?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
One. As well as -1AC, -1 to the Fort save, and -40 hit points. If I've got my sums right, you can still take Dev Crit at the same level. You'd have to be careful about armour, though, if you're going on a more caster route - which means knowing your environment and what's coming, and when.

And, as I mentioned earlier, you won't need Dev Crit in Aielund (if that's where you want to play the build), 'cause it don't exist, which opens up other feats.

Cheers

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: This brute wields a two-hander for the extra damage from the 1,5 x strength bonus. But he is also a "Dever", and for a medium sized creature 19-20 is the best threat range available for a two hander. Of course you can improve on that with Improved Critical, Keen and also Ki critical if you're a Weapon master. 
Small characters, like gnomes, halflings and such can use the Scimitar with it's 18-20 threat range as a two hander, but then again, they are not quite so strong.
Now, threat range is not everything. You also have to actually land and confirm a critical hit. And here AB is crucial. On top of that you have to beat the fort save of your target with your Dev crit DC.
While waiting for all that to happen, it is good to know that you can deal some heavy damage.
I finally worked out my mistake. I guess there are no Falchions in the game then.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
There may be Falchions in modules that use the Community Expansion Pack (CEP).
The weapons included in the CEP are of limited value since they cannot be chosen when selecting a weapon-specific feat.
So unfortunately there will be no Dev crit for Falchions.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Unless Beamdog finally decides to incorporate into the game the CEP weapons...
And while they doing this, they could also implement some other stuff like making Dragon-shape able to take all the combat-related feats like WS/EWS, Dev Crit, etc.
And it would be great if you could just click the Expertise/Power attack button and it stays there until you click again on it. Like NWN2 & IWD2 did.
And fix the dreadful companion A.I so that they have a better I.Q than broccoli.
There are so many things they could/should do, I could write down stuff for ages, but I prefer to be optimistic about this.
I would buy such an Enhanced Edition without a second thought, just to support the game even if I do not play the game anymore.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote: ...just to support the game even if I do not play the game anymore.
??? What in the Abyss is that supposed to mean? Have a word with yourself, will you! I know I can't play atm (hope that will be resolved in the new year) - but choosing not to? I'm tempted to send the big girls round for a serious discussion - an intervention may be required...😱😞

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Ouch!...
How did this come to the attention of Lord Baratheon himself?
Err, yes sir...Aye, will do that.
Runs far, far away...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, he keeps his eye on his beloved troops. Ensures their well-being - and makes damned sure they don't just bugger off when they feel like it!
Good man, sir (after all, I still have plenty of idiot questions to ask!)
And you do know, I presume, that there is no distance you could run...

Festive greetings to all my good friends here! It's always a joy.

posts.author: Elgirts
posts.content:
Okay, first off, Hello!  
First time posting here.

I was inspired by Valerfor's "PANTHRO" build. 
I am in no way an expert. In fact you could call me a green noob. I hope I am not violating protocol by jumping in here to ask this, but my curiosity led me down this path.

I want to use this build as a template for starting into my games. I started playing him to see how it "feels" and I love the concept of the brute force steamroller that Panthro represents. While playing, him, it started my RP story developing gears turning and an idea hit me. Can this build be modified down to a Gnome carrying a warhammer? Granted I will lose the +2 to strength of the Half-Orc, and further more lose an additional -2 to Strength by classing down to a Gnome, but would the build still be viable? I'm pretty certain that changing the race like this drastically changes everything, If so how would you change it around to make it work?  

For RP purposes, I am envisioning a small unimposing gnome that everyone teases for always carrying around his over sized warhammer. (Well, over sized for him at least) However, whenever the sh*t hits the fan, he suddenly rushes in cracking ankles and smashing kneecaps. To the casual observer, once he runs into the battle, all you see is these foes looking down trying to swing at something unseen while every few seconds a body drops mysteriously.

Thanks in advance.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello Elgirts! Welcome aboard our wee ship of miscreants!

And you pick a beautiful build to go for in your first few run-throughs (always good to see a fellow non-caster).

Are you absolutely sure your gnome couldn't be wielding a scimitar (just think of it as a flattened war hammer, if that helps)?

Regardless, there's absolutely no reason you couldn't gnomify Panthro - you're still left with a very healthy AB and Dev Crit, although of course you would lose the 1.5 damage multiplier from your weapon, 'cos your gnome couldn't wield it. Still, fun and rp wins out, so hurrah!

posts.author: Elgirts
posts.content:
Thank you for the welcome. 

The scimitar is not off the table. In fact it is a possible option. I was thinking that the Warhammer would give more bludgeoning damage, (Dunno of that makes a difference at all) however, the Scimitar could be worked into my vision/stories. What is the benefit of the Scimitar over the Warhammer?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, it's neither better nor worse than war hammer in itself, it's just that it gives you a better chance of landing a Dev Crit. In a non-Dev Crit world I'd be more tempted by war hammer as a x3 agony-giver, rather than x2, but it's only a 20 crit (19-20 with Imp Crit), while your scimitar crits at 18-20 without Imp Crit (15-20 with it). So, it's all about raising your chances of that one hit kill.

Does that make sense?

posts.author: Elgirts
posts.content:
It certainly does. Make sense.  Thanks, and I should have seen it right away. I might just have to make both versions and see which one "feels" right when I play it. I could go with the numbers, but if I did that, a lot of other builds would appeal top me. What it's gonna come down to is how it "feels" when I play it. Remember, this Gnome is supposed to be standing out because he is carrying a ridiculous weapon for his size. If I can get that effect with the scimitar, or if the play somehow makes the Gnome stand out then I'll make that work. :)   

The original (PANTHRO) build as a whole fits my style of play so far, and is a real joy to play. Now to see if the Gnome generates the same feeling in the game. 
Thanks again for the feedback. It is much appreciated.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
With Gnome you start with strength 16. The strength bonus from RDD will still let you take O.Crit and Dev Crit as planned.
Small folk wield medium sized weapons as two handers, so you retain the 1,5 bonus to damage. The lower strength gives a lower AB,damage and Dev Crit DC, but small size gives you back some of the AB.
Dispite the small size, this one is going to wreak havoc. Wielding a Scimitar gives a threat range that no normal large weapon can match.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: Small folk wield medium sized weapons as two handers, so you retain the 1,5 bonus to damage.
I didn't know that about the damage retention - very useful info, thanks Mick!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Changing from Half-Orc to Gnome gives you an effective -4 STR, but also +2 CON, +2 INT (compared to Half-Orc), and +2 CHA (Compared to Half-Orc), a net gain of 2 points.  You could decide to keep the same starting INT, putting those 2 points into DEX so you can take advantage of the +1 DEX AC allowed with heavy armor.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
If nothing else, you will be more devastating with a scimitar wielded two-handed, Elgirts.
And, welcome to the ECB man!

posts.author: Elgirts
posts.content:
I ended up going with the scimitar variant. It looked way cooler with the way he balances the blade on his shoulder. It fit better in the RP vision I was creating for him. Plus, I have now added to his storyline that he likes to try to intimidate people by slapping the blade in his palm before a fight. (Imagine the scene from Conan the Barbarian where Valeria taunts a couple of foes during a fight in the caves. The scene where she slaps the blade of her scimitar against her palm to lure them to attack her.)

Empyre65, I came to the same conclusion and decided to move the +2 from INT to DEX for that +1 AC

Can someone look at the skills at level 21? I can't tell if my math is off or not. I'm getting only 4 skill saves as instead of the 5 indicated.

Otherwise, I am very happy with how this turned out. Thank you guys.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hmm, not sure about the skills issue. I take it that it hasn't been a problem before, and now you've got RDD9 (with its INT boost) under your belt you've got that extra skill point...It couldn't be human error, could it? You know, popping an extra point in somewhere before it's due - I know I've done that before a stupid amount of times. But you do catch up with yourself eventually.
